S2095-4956(23)00072-4 10.1016/j.jechem.2023.01.053 Science Press and Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the synthesis procedure of CBC/SnS2/S and CBC/SOSC. Fig. 2 Morphology and elemental information of cathodic materials. (a, b) SEM images of CBC/SnS2. (c) SEM image of CBC/SnS2/S. (d) TEM image and (e, f) HRTEM images of CBC/SnS2. The lattice distances of 0.58 and 0.32 nm correspond to the (001) and (100) crystallographic planes of the hexagonal SnS2, respectively. (g) STEM and EDS mapping image of CBC/SnS2. Fig. 3 Morphology, elemental information, and contact angle (CA) measurement of the interlayers. (a) SEM, digital image and (b) TEM of CBC/SOSC; (c) HRTEM image of ht-CNFs; (d, e) HRTEM images, (f) SAED image, (g) STEM image and EDS mapping image of CBC/SnO2–SnS2; (h) CA measurements of the BC, CBC and CBC/SOSC interlayer. Fig. 4 Structure and bonding information of the sulfur host CBC/SnS2 and multifunctional interlayer CBC/SOSC. (a) XRD patterns. Three main peaks located at around 14.8°, 28.3°, and 32.2° are assigned to the diffraction of the (001), (100), and (101) planes of SnS2 (JCPDS No. 23–0677). (b) Raman spectra. (c) N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms and the inset pore-size distributions (inset) that are obtained from the adsorption isotherms with Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method; specific surface areas are calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. (d) XPS survey spectra. (e) XPS Sn 3d and (f) S 2p spectra. Fig. 5 (a) Schematic illustration of set-up for the cell in which the cathode works with the interlayer. (b) CV curves from 1.6 to 2.8 V vs. Li+/Li at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1, (c) Nyquist plots of cells after pre-cycled for 3cycles at 0.2 C for activation and the corresponding fitting results using equivalent circuit (inset), (d) rate performance, (e) galvanostatic charge/discharge curves in which we denote the two typical platforms in the discharge curves as ΔQ 1 and ΔQ 2, corresponding to the different electrocatalytic activity of reducing sulfur to Li2S n and subsequently converting to insoluble Li2S, respectively; (f) cycle performance at 0.5 C, (g) cycle performance at 1.5 C with pre-cycling at 0.2 C for 5cycles, (h) Li+ diffusion coefficient at different peaks of CV curves of different samples. (i) cycle performance at 0.3 C with high sulfur loadings (70 wt% sulfur content in electrode) of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC. Fig. 6 (a) UV-vis spectra of CBC, CBC/SnS2, and CBC/SOSC, and inset digital image showing the Li2S6 absorption by CBC (II), CBC/SnS2 (III) and CBC/SOSC (IV); (b) digital images of Li2S8 solution permeation measurements by different interlayers with PP; (c) C 1s, (d) Sn 3d, (e) O 1s and (f) S 2p XPS spectra of CBC/SOSC after Li2S6 adsorption; (g) CV plots of symmetric batteries assembled with different electrodes; potentiostatic discharge profiles of (h) CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC at 2.05 V; (i) the scheme of Li2S n absorption-conversion through the synergy of CBC/SnS2 and CBC/SOSC. Fig. 7 (a) Voltage profiles at 0.5 mA cm−2 (0.25 mA h cm−2) of Li||Li symmetric batteries with the interlayer of CBC/SOSC or CBC, and without an interlayer; SEM images after cycling of lithium symmetric batteries without (b) an interlayer, with the interlayer of (c) CBC, and (d) CBC/SOSC; (e) voltage profiles at various current densities (0.5, 1, 2, 5 and 10 mA cm−2, respectively); (f) voltage profiles at 10 mA cm−2 (5 mA h cm−2) of lithium symmetric batteries with the CBC/SOSC interlayer and without an interlayer. Fig. 8 SEM images after cycling of different cathodes (a–d) and Li anodes (e–h); (i) schematic illustration of the synergy effect CBC/SnS2/S and CBC/SOSC that enhances the electrochemistry in LSBs. Simultaneous realization of high sulfur utilization and lithium dendrite-free via dual-effect kinetic regulation strategy toward lithium-sulfur batteries Xinqi Zhao a Xiaohong Sun a ⁎ Ruisong Guo a ⁎ Song Wang a Fuyun Li a Tingting Li a Wen Zhang a Chunming Zheng a Lingyun An b Leichao Meng b Xudong Hu c ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Advanced Ceramics and Machining Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Ceramics and Machining Technology of Ministry of Education School of Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China Key Laboratory of Advanced Ceramics and Machining Technology of Ministry of Education, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University, Tianjin 300072, China b Qinghai Provincial Key Laboratory of Nanomaterials and Technology, School of Physics and Electronic Information Engineering, Qinghai Minzu University, Xining 810007, Qinghai, China Qinghai Provincial Key Laboratory of Nanomaterials and Technology School of Physics and Electronic Information Engineering Qinghai Minzu University Xining 810007 Qinghai China Qinghai Provincial Key Laboratory of Nanomaterials and Technology, School of Physics and Electronic Information Engineering, Qinghai Minzu University, Xining 810007, Qinghai, China c Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry University of California Santa Barbara CA 93106 United States Department of Chemistry & Biochemistry, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106, United States ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract A systematic design of stepwise catalytic-adsorption-conversion for sulfur species via the synergetic of efficient catalytic cathode (CBC/SnS2/S) and light multifunctional interlayer (CBC/SOSC) has been proposed to synchronously enhance sulfur utilization and inhibit lithium-dendrite for LSBs. With the high theoretical specific capacity and energy density, lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have been intensively studied as promising candidates for energy storage devices. However, LSBs are largely hindered by inferior sulfur utilization and uncontrollable dendritic growth. Herein, a hierarchical functionalization strategy of stepwise catalytic-adsorption-conversion for sulfur species via the synergetic of the efficiently catalytic host cathode and light multifunctional interlayer has been proposed to concurrently address the issues arising on the dual sides of the LSBs. The multi-layer SnS2 micro-flowers embedded into the natural three-dimensional (3D) interconnected carbonized bacterial cellulose (CBC) nanofibers are fabricated as the sulfur host that provides numerous catalytic sites for the rapid catalytic conversion of sulfur species. Moreover, the distinctive CBC-based SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure network accompanied high conductive carbon nanofibers as the multifunctional interlayer promotes the rapid anchoring-diffusion-conversion of lithium polysulfides, Li+ flux redistribution, and uniform Li deposition. LSBs equipped with our strategy exhibit a high reversible capacity of 1361.5 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and superior cycling stability with an ultra-low capacity fading of 0.031% per cycle in 1000 cycles at 1.5 C and 0.046% at 3 C. A favorable specific capacity of 859.5 mA h g−1 at 0.3 C is achieved with a high sulfur mass loading of 5.2 mg cm−2, highlighting the potential of practical application. The rational design in this work can provide a feasible solution for high-performance LSBs and promote the development of advanced energy storage devices. Keywords Lithium-sulfur battery Catalytic sulfur host Multifunctional interlayer Polysulfides adsorbing-conversion Dendrite-free 1 Introduction Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) have been commercialized for a long time and pursued in many fields such as portable electronics and electric vehicles [1,2]. Limited by the low energy density, LIBs are far from meeting the growing market demands. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) with high theoretical specific capacity (∼1675 mA h g−1) and energy density (∼2600 W h kg−1) are regarded as promising alternatives to LIBs [3,4]. However, the development of LSBs has been hindered by a series of challenges of the sulfur cathode that has a serious volume expansion during cycling, the insulation of both sulfur and polysulfides, and the shuttling effect of soluble long-chain lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) [5–7]. These detrimental issues lead to poor rate capability, rapid capacity decay, and non-negligible corrosion of the lithium anode. To solve the problems mentioned above, intensive efforts have been adopted in regard to cathode materials modification, including heterogeneous doping of conductive materials and compositing with carbon materials, transition metal oxides/sulfides/nitrides, and metal alloys [8–10]. Notably, carbon/metal sulfide composites have been regarded as the universal sulfur host materials in which the carbon component delivers excellent electrical conductivity and mechanical flexibility, while the metal sulfides, such as FeS2, MoS2, TiS2, and Co3S4, play an important role in catalyzing the conversion of sulfur species, expediting the redox kinetics, and boosting the sulfur utilization of the cathode [11]. However, the carbon/metal sulfide sulfur host materials still suffer from the polysulfide-shuttling behavior, held back by their sluggish redox kinetics that mainly results from the limited active sites, especially under the condition of high sulfur loadings [4,5]. Therefore, the enhancement of rapid electrocatalytic capability for the conversion from sulfur to polysulfides is imperative to realize high-performance sulfur cathodes [12,13]. There are other two challenges facing the LSBs: (1) The unstable structure of LSBs which is mainly caused by the inferior anchoring ability of soluble polysulfides on the cathodic side and (2) the violent corrosion and lithium-dendrite formation that happen on the anodic side. The both challenges will result in inevitable performance degradation and serious safety issues [14,15]. Pioneering studies have demonstrated that introducing functional interlayers in the cells can alleviate the two problems [16–18]. On the one hand, the interlayers can effectively block and convert the polysulfides that are dissolved in the electrolyte, thus improving the utilization of sulfur and enhancing the capacity and cycling performance of LSBs. On the other hand, the interlayers can act as a hinder to inhibit the migration of polysulfides so that the anodic corrosion can be alleviated and the lithium-dendrite formation can be suppressed by the interlayers through reducing the uneven lithium deposition [19,20]. To achieve the outstanding functions mentioned above, the interlayer is required excellent electrolyte wettability for rapid Li+ transfer, strong physical/chemical adsorption of polysulfides, and high catalytic activity to accelerate the conversion of LiPSs. The capability of rapid LiPSs anchoring-conversion is also important, which can avoid the LiPSs accumulation to damage the interlayer, prevent the low sulfur utilization caused by the polysulfides shuttling, and ensure the structural stability of lithium anode [13,18]. Among the studied materials, metal oxide/sulfide heterostructures with strong chemisorption, unique conductive heterointerface, and rapid LiPSs catalytic conversion, have been reported as ideal materials for functional interlayers [21–23]. However, intensive efforts have been reported to improve the defects of cathode or anode through modifying cathode materials or introducing interlayers, but few systematic designs have simultaneously alleviated all the above issues in dual-side electrodes. Herein, we demonstrated a novel strategy to synchronously tackle the aforementioned problems on cathode and anode of LSBs via the synergetic of the efficient catalytic host cathode and light multifunctional interlayer. Both the sulfur host and the multifunctional interlayer based on an interconnected carbonized bacterial cellulose network (CBC) are co-applied to deliver their specifial functions in LSBs. The low-cost CBC with intrinsic 3D interconnected porous network structure can accommodate the tremendous volume change of transformed sulfur, offer physical adsorption to suppress the shuttling effect, and accelerate the Li+ diffusion during cycling [24,25]. The sulfur host, CBC/SnS2, that the distinctive multi-layer SnS2 micro-flowers densely trapped in CBC network provides abundant active sites for catalyzing the conversion of sulfur and polysulfides. The 3D “network-flowers” framework can also afford a short diffusion pathway for Li+ and electron, remarkably enhancing the redox reaction kinetics. A hierarchical structure of SnO2–SnS2 heterostructures coated on the nanofibers of the CBC network coordinating high-conductivity carbon nanofibers (ht-CNFs) was fabricated as the multifunctional interlayer (CBC/SOSC). CBC/SOSC can rapidly capture soluble LiPSs via the strong adsorption and accelerate the catalytic conversion, realizing the enhanced regulation of LiPSs from capture to conversion. In addition, the significance of CBC/SOSC for safety issues arising on the anodic side was highlighted. CBC/SOSC can promote the uniform Li deposition, which suppressed the lithium-dendrite formation and improved the stability of SEI formation. Taking advantages of the merits of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC, the cell delivered an enhanced reversible capacity of 1361.5 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C, an ultra-low-capacity attenuation of 0.031% per cycle in 1000 cycles at 1.5C. A remarkable reversible capacity of 859.5 mA h g−1 at 0.3 C was achieved with a high sulfur mass loading of 5.2 mg cm−2, validating the potential practical application for LSBs. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterizations of the cathode host and interlayer The overall synthesis procedure of CBC/SnS2/S and CBC/SOSC interlayer are schematically illustrated in Fig. 1 . Both materials are based on the BC aerogel. Typically, the BC aerogels with abundant hydroxyl groups were prepared by freeze-drying BC hydrogels [24]. For CBC/SnS2/S cathode, the CBC nanofibers were firstly obtained after high-temperature carbonization of the BC aerogel. Then, CBC was subjected to hydrothermal treatment for a sulfurization reaction with SnCl4⋅5H2O and CH3CSNH2 (TAA) as the tin and sulfur sources, respectively. After the sulfurization reaction by the hydrothermal treatment, the multi-layer SnS2 micro-flowers were trapped in the 3D interconnected carbon network structure. Subsequently, the sulfur was homogeneously melt-diffused in the interior of SnS2 micro-flowers and CBC nanofibers to fabricate the cathode material CBC/SnS2/S. The sulfur content of 76.73 wt% in CBC/SnS2/S was determined by TG measurement (Fig. S1). CBC in sulfur host plays a positive role in alleviating the volume change of sulfur as well as accelerating the electron transfers [24,25]. For the fabrication of CBC/SOSC, BC aerogel was punched into a wafer and immersed into the solution with SnCl4⋅5H2O and CH4N2S followed by a hydrothermal and annealing process. The aerogel fibers with charged and abundant oxygen-containing functional hydroxyl groups show strong electrostatic attraction to Sn4+ through Lewis acid-base interactions, which assures the homogeneous distribution of tin-based compound intermediates to form the uniform SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure particles [24–27]. Then, the prepared 3D CBC/SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure network was stirred with solution accompanied by ht-CNFs (derived by carbonized BC aerogel at the high temperature of 1000 °C) and CBC/SOSC interlayer was finally obtained via a freeze-drying process. SEM and TEM images in Fig. 2 (a, b, and d) show that the multi-layer SnS2 micro-flowers formed by aggregated nanosheets with a diameter of 1.5 μm are uniformly trapped in the CBC. The 3D network structural nanofibers of BC aerogel and CBC are shown in Fig. S2. Fig. 2(c) shows the SEM image of CBC/SnS2 host with the sulfur loading. The sulfurs are evenly dispersed in SnS2 micro-flowers, which provides abundant active sites to promote the catalytic conversion of sulfur and polysulfides, facilitates the Li+ diffusion, and enhances the redox reaction kinetics [28–31]. Hexagonal SnS2 with good crystallinity existed in CBC/SnS2 (Fig. 2e and f, Fig. S3). The scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mappings in Fig. 2(g) show uniform distributions of C, Sn, and S elements throughout CBC/SnS2, which further confirms the structure that the SnS2 micro-flowers are embedded in the interconnected CBC network and is favorable for the transport of ions and structural stability during the polysulfides conversion [32–35]. SEM and TEM were also carried out to characterize the morphology of the multifunctional interlayer CBC/SOSC. The SEM image in Fig. 3 (a) shows that CBC/SOSC has coadjacent thick nanofibers adhered by uniform particles. CBC/SOSC exhibits enhanced toughness and flexibility while ensuring its lightness and thinness compared to the pure CBC interlayer (Fig. S4). As displayed in Fig. 3(b), there are two types of nanofibers corresponding to the ht-CNFs and CBC/SnO2–SnS2. The interspersed ht-CNFs (Fig. 3c) in the CBC/SOSC interlayer can effectively strengthen the conductivity of the interlayer, promote ion diffusion and alleviate the increase in resistance of battery caused by the addition of an external layer [36,37]. It can be clearly seen in Fig. 3(d) that the nanoparticles attach to the surface of CBC fibers. HRTEM images in Fig. 3(e) and Fig. S5 show that the adjacent nanoparticles have interplanar crystal spacings of 0.59 and 0.34 nm corresponding to the (001) plane of SnS2 and the (110) plane of SnO2, respectively, which demonstrates the formation of SnO2–SnS2 heterointerface. And in the SAED pattern (Fig. 3f), a set of well-defined diffraction rings are perfectly indexed to be the (001) and (100) planes of hexagonal SnS2 as well as the (110) plane of hexagonal SnO2, respectively, which further confirms the SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure [30,31]. The uniform distribution of C, Sn, S, and O in CBC/SOSC further confirms the homogeneous distribution of SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure on the surface of CBC (Fig. 3g). In addition, the interlayer wettability toward the electrolytes was tested by the contact angle (CA) measurements. As depicted in Fig. 3(h), CBC/SOSC exhibits a prominent electrolyte wettability with a low contact angle of 3.6° after 5 s, which is much lower than that of BC (40.8°) and CBC (23.5°). This phenomenon suggests that the SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure uniformly formed on the CBC surface facilitates the penetration of the electrolyte in the interlayer, guaranteeing the fast ionic propagation during polysulfide conversion and reaction with Li+ [38]. The crystalline phases of the prepared CBC/SnS2 and CBC/SOSC were determined by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) as shown in Fig. 4 (a). For CBC/SnS2, all diffraction peaks belong to SnS2 without any impurity phase. CBC is undetectable because the XRD pattern in Fig. S6(a) reveals that CBC is disordered carbon material. For the XRD pattern of CBC/SOSC (Fig. 4a), diffraction peaks can be readily indexed to be hexagonal phase SnO2 (JPCD No. 46–1088) and SnS2 (JCPDS No. 23–0677), implying the existence of SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure. The two bands at 1,337 and 1,583 cm−1 in the Raman spectra (Fig. 4b) are the D band and G band of carbon, which are attributed to the A1g breathing-mode vibration of C6 rings activated by the existing defects, and the E2g vibration of sp 2-bonded carbon pairs, respectively [24,28]. The low I D/IG ratio of CBC/SnS2 (0.72) suggests a relatively high graphitization degree of CBC, which is essential to the enhanced conductivity of the cathode [16,25]. The relatively high I D/IG values (1.20) of CBC/SOSC can be attributed to the abundant defects caused by SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure particles stably anchoring onto the CBC, which is favorable for electron propagation through the interlayer [23,28]. The ht-CNFs in CBC/SOSC interlayer are also beneficial for alleviating the increase of internal resistance caused by extra interlayer as well as for guaranteeing rapid Li+ migration [29–32]. The both spectra all display an intense peak at 315 cm−1, which is ascribed to the A1g lattice vibration mode of SnS2 [27]. Raman spectrum of CBC/SOSC in Fig. S6(b) shows other peaks at 480, and 625 cm−1. The both peaks correspond well to band S2, and mode A1g, respectively, due to the Sn-O stretching [30,33]. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms in Fig. 4(c) are typical type-IV, suggesting mesoporous characteristics of CBC/SnS2 and CBC/SOSC. The insets of Fig. 4(c) and Fig. S7 show that the pore sizes existing inside CBC/SnS2 and CBC/SOSC distribute from 3 to 10 nm. Despite the mesopores, CBC/SnS2 has a relatively low specific surface area (SSA) of 77 m2 g−1 due to the high SnS2 content. The high SSA of CBC/SOSC (132.67 m2 g−1) is favorable for the LiPS absorption. The pore size of CBC/SOSC is compatible with the size of long-order polysulfide species (Li2S8, ∼2 nm), which makes the absorption favorable and thus improves the sulfur utilization of LSBs [34]. The bonding status of CBC/SnS2 and CBC/SOSC was analyzed by XPS. The full spectra in Fig. S8(a) reveal the existence of C, Sn, O, and S elements in CBC/SnS2 and CBC/SOSC. The assigned peaks located at 495.3 and 486.8 eV from Sn 3d spectra of CBC/SnS2 and CBC/SOSC present the Sn 3d 3/2 and Sn 3d 5/2 due to the Sn–S bond (Fig. 4e). It is worthy to note that additional peaks (494.7 and 485.9 eV) can be assigned to S–Sn–O bond for the Sn 3d spectrum of CBC/SOSC, which can be attributed to the SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure [31]. In the S 2p spectrum (Fig. 4f), the two peaks of S 2p 1/2 and S 2p 3/2 located at 161.7 and 162.8 eV can be assigned to the S–Sn bond of SnS2 and the extra peaks (164.7 and 166.4 eV) belong to the SC bond, indicating the intensive binding between SnS2 and CBC [35]. The C 1s and O 1s spectra in Fig. S8 further convince the intensive SnS2–CBC binding and presence of the SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure in CBC/SOSC. 2.2 Electrochemical performances Fig. 5 (a) shows the structure of the coin-type cells used in this work to investigate the electrochemical performances of the cathode that works with the interlayer. Cells with CBC/S cathode, CBC/SnS2/S cathode, and CBC/SnS2/S cathode combined CBC interlayer (CBC/SnS2/S@CBC) were assembled separately to highlight the synergetic strategy of CBC/SnS2/S cathode and CBC/SOSC multi-functional interlayer when applied to LSBs. All the CV curves show similar shapes, including two distinct cathodic peaks and one anodic peak (Fig. 5b). The cathodic peak at high potential (2.15–2.28 V vs. Li+/Li, Peak 1) is associated with the reduction of sulfur to high-order soluble long-chain Li2S n (4 ≤ n ≤ 8), while the other one at low potential (1.9–2.02 V vs. Li+/Li, Peak 2) is related to the further reduction of soluble long-chain polysulfides to insoluble short-chain Li2S/Li2S2 precipitation on the cathode [39]. Additionally, the anodic peak (2.15–2.28 V vs. Li+/Li, Peak 3) looks much broad compared with the cathodic ones. Actually, two peaks overlap and merge to be one, which corresponds to the reversible conversion of short-chain to long-chain LiPSs, and finally to sulfur. The phenomenon of overlapping and merging of the both peaks could be attributed to the fast reaction kinetics of the oxidation of polysulfides to sulfur [40–42]. It is worth noting that CBC/SnS2/S has its CV with a reduced overpotential, featuring the positive shift of the cathodic peaks and the negative shift of the anodic peak compared with CBC/S. This indicates the enhanced S–Li2S n –Li2S/Li2S2–Li2S n –S conversion due to the abundant active sites of SnS2 micro-flowers [27]. Moreover, CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC delivers a much more positive-shifted cathodic peak of 2.2 V vs. Li+/Li compared with CBC/SnS2/S@CBC, demonstrating that SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure can facilitate the liquid–solid conversion from the soluble long-chain Li2S n and insoluble short-chain Li2S/Li2S2. The facilitation can be illustrated by the Nernst Eq. (1). (1) E = E 0 - RT zF l n Q Where E is reduction potential, E 0 is the standard potential, R is the universal gas constant, T is the temperature in Kelvin, z is the ion charge of the reaction, F is the Faraday constant, and Q is the reaction quotient that is related to the amounts of products and reactants present during the reaction. When half-cell reaction on the cathodic side at 1.9–2.02 V vs. Li+/Li is simply regarded as. LiS n + ( n - 2 ) Li + + ( n - 2 ) e - → n Li 2 S The Nernst Equation (1) based on the half-cell reaction can be correctly and formally re-written in terms of the concentrations of products and reactants as Eq. (2). (2) E = E 0 - RT n - 2 F l n C L i 2 S n C L i S n C L i + n - 2 Where C L i S n , C Li + , and C Li 2 S are the concentrations of LiS n , Li+, and Li2S on the cathodic side, respectively. Considering that the product, Li2S, is solid, C Li 2 S is regarded as the constant of 1, then Eq. (2) can be simplified to be the following Eq. (3). (3) E = E 0 + RT ( n - 2 ) ln C ( LiS n ) C ( Li + ) ( n - 2 ) Since C Li + of the electrolyte used in the cells is a constant, it is clear that the reduction potential, E is positively correlated with the concentration of LiS n on the cathodic side of the cell. It can be concluded that the positive-shift of the cathodic peak of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC results from the high concentration of LiS n on the cathodic side of the cell compared to the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC, demonstrating the enhanced LiS n -adsorption-holding ability and effective electrocatalysis performance of the interconnected SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure nanofiber network in CBC/SOSC interlayer. Due to the advantages of synergy between CBC/SnS2 host and CBC/SOSC interlayer, the overpotential (ΔE) between the redox peaks of the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC (0.43 V) is much lower than that of CBC/S (0.72 V), CBC/SnS2/S (0.53 V) and CBC/SnS2/S@CBC (0.50 V), highlighting the enhanced LiS n -adsorption and liquid–solid (Li2S n -Li2S/Li2S2) conversion ability of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC. The advantage of electrochemical redox kinetics in CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC can also be proven by the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) in Fig. S9. All the Nyquist plots are composed of semicircles in the high- and medium-frequency regions and one oblique straight line in the low-frequency region and can be fitted by an equivalent circuit (Fig. 5c). The R e, R ct, and R s represent the resistance of the electrolyte, the charge transfer resistance from the conductive interface, and the resistance of the deposition of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film, respectively. Z w represents the Warburg impedance of the diffusion of LiPSs within the cathode. It is worthy noting that CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC delivers the lowest R ct (22.31 Ω, Table S1) among all the samples, attributing to the fast polysulfide conversion kinetics provided by SnS2 micro-flowers. Moreover, the lowest Z w can result from the SnO2–SnS2 heterointerface that facilitates ion diffusion [33]. The low R s indicates that CBC/SOSC interlayer reduces, to a large extent, the deposition of SEI films on the lithium anode, which can result in a reduction of the internal resistance of the LSBs and thus an enhancement of the specific capacity, rate capability, and cycling stability of the cell [43,44]. As a result of the enhanced reaction and diffusion kinetics, CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC achieves much improved rate capability. Reversible capacities of 1361.5, 1088.1, 983.4, 879.5, 750.3, and 592.8 mA h g−1 are delivered at the current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, and 3 C, respectively (Fig. 5d). The corresponding galvanostatic charge/discharge (GCD) curves (Fig. S10) also verify the lowest overpotential of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC among the four samples, which is consistent with the CV results discussed above (Fig. 5b). Moreover, GCD curves at 0.5 C (Fig. 5e) show that CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC has the large ΔQ 1 and the high ΔQ 2/ΔQ 1 of 2.63 (Fig. S11), indicating simultaneous enhancements of the S–Li2S n and Li2S n –Li2S conversions due to the combination of the SnS2 micro-flowers of cathodic host with the SnO2–SnS2 heterostructures in the multifunctional interlayer. Among all the samples, CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC delivers the highest initial capacity of 1185.5 mA h g−1 and a capacity of 948.2 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at 0.5 C, with a capacity retention of 80.0%. This capacity retention is higher than those of CBCS/S@CBC (71.7%), CBC/SnS2/S (60.4%) and CBC/S (41.1%) as shown in Fig. 5(f). The improved cycling stability of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC can be derived from the 3D tightly interconnected carbon network of CBC and the inhibition of polysulfides shuttling, and the enhanced reversibility of electrochemical reaction caused by uniformly distributed SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure [47,48]. The overlapped GCD curves during the 300-cycle test (Fig. S12a) of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC indicate excellent electrochemical stability and high sulfur utilization [40], while the three other samples display capacity degradation and huge polarization during cycling (Fig. S12b–d). The long-cycling performance in Fig. 5(g) shows that CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC delivers a high capacity of 584.5 mA h g−1 at 1.5 C after 1000 cycles with a capacity decay of only 0.031% per cycle, which is much lower than those in CBC/SnS2/S@CBC (0.045%) and CBC/SnS2/S (0.058%). The capacity retention of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC can keep 66.7%. Even at 3 C, the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC shows a high capacity-retention of 80.9% from 570.6 mA h g−1 to 461.6 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles (Fig. S13). The Li+ diffusion coefficients (D Li+) at Peak 1, 2, and 3 were calculated based on the CV curves (Fig. S14) at different scan rates (calculation details in Supporting Information). As shown in Fig. 5(h) and Table S2, CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC has the highest D Li+ of 10.51, 9.55, and 21.84 × 10−9 cm2 s−1 for Peak 1, 2, and 3, respectively. The enhanced D Li+ of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC demonstrates the low internal resistance and fast kinetics process, which are provided by the highly conductive 3D interconnected carbon-based network and unique SnO2–SnS2 heterointerface of the multifunctional CBC/SOSC interlayer [49–52]. Moreover, the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC cells with 3.1 and 5.0 mg cm−2 sulfur loadings can deliver remarkable discharge capacities of 998.6 and 859.5 mA h g−1, respectively at 0.3 C, without obvious capacity fading after 100 cycles (Fig. 5i), highlighting the application potential of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC for LSBs [49]. Fig. S15 indicates that CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC cell with 5.0 mg cm−2 sulfur loadings provides a high discharge specific capacity of 688.3 mA h g−1 after 250 cycles at 1 C. Besides, the respective cycle performance of CBC/SnS2/S cathode and CBC/SOSC interlayer have been explored at 1 C (Fig. S16). LSB with CBC/SnS2/S cathode shows the high initial discharge specific capacity, and CBC/SOSC interlayer displays excellent cycling stability. We can thus conclude that the excellent electrochemical performance of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC results from the advantage of the synergy between the CBC/SnS2/S cathode and the multifunctional CBC/SOSC interlayer. 2.3 Absorption-conversion effect of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC on high sulfur utilization To visually investigate the adsorbing effect of the as-prepared samples toward polysulfides, a static adsorption experiment was carried out by placing the samples of CBC, CBC/SnS2, and CBC/SOSC into Li2S6 solutions (3 mM). As shown in Fig. 6 (a), the Li2S6 solution exhibits an original golden yellow in the blank sample. Compared with CBC and CBC/SnS2, the color of the solution with CBC/SOSC fad to almost transparent after 10 h, suggesting the outcoming polysulfides adsorption capability of CBC/SOSC [41]. The adsorption capabilities of polysulfides are also confirmed by ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) absorption spectroscopy using solutions after the adsorption reaction. The broad absorbance peaks of Li2S6 appear at around 420 nm in all samples. It is displayed the solution of CBC/SOSC samples shows the weakest LiPSs absorption peaks, indicating the effective anchoring ability of CBC/SOSC towards the LiPSs [45]. To study the holding effect of the CBC/SOSC interlayer on polysulfide, polysulfide-shuttling experiments with Li2S8 solution on PP separator, PP@CBC interlayer, and PP@CBC/SOSC interlayer were carried out (Fig. 6b). There is no obvious color change that can be perceived for the solution in the right chamber for PP@CBC/SOSC interlayer sample after 9 h, suggesting that the interlayer can efficiently inhibit the polysulfide shuttling [38]. To reveal the mechanism behind the strong interaction forces of CBC/SOSC towards LiPSs, the surface chemistry of CBC/SOSC after the adsorption experiment was examined by XPS measurement. As exhibited in Fig. S17 and Fig. 6(c–f), for C 1s spectra, there is no obvious binding energy shift corresponding to the only weak physical imprisonment between CBC and LiPSs [24,25]. As exhibited in Fig. 6(d), Sn 3d peaks of CBC/SOSC-Li2S6 shift toward lower binding energy with regard to that of the pristine CBC/SOSC, demonstrating the increased the electron density located at the metal center and strong chemical interaction. Contracting to the pristine O 1s spectra, the chemical adsorption of Li2S6 (Fig. 6e) induces an additional peak at 526.8 eV, which could be explained by that oxygen gains electrons after interacting with Li in LiPSs [55]. This also represents the chemical bonding between O and Li, which can be donated as the Li–O bond [55]. Meanwhile, the S 2p peaks of CBC/SOSC–Li2S6 (Fig. 6f) shift toward higher binding energy than that of the pristine CBC/SOSC, indicating a higher chemical anchoring function toward LiPSs. Furthermore, the additional peaks located at higher BE areas are associated with polythionate and thiosulfate, respectively. The chemical shift is attributed to the oxidization of Li2S6 to intermediate species since the high-valance ions propel the formation of polythionate/thiosulfate groups [53–55]. Moreover, the coexistence of polythionate and thiosulfate species in the S 2p spectrum indicates that CBC/SOSC has a good catalytic effect on polysulfides conversion besides the adsorption of LiPSs [46,53]. To investigate the catalytic effect and reaction kinetics of materials after anchoring LiPSs, the symmetric batteries of CBC, CBC/SnS2, CBC/SnS2@CBC, and CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC were assembled by using the same working and counter electrodes with 5 mM Li2S6 electrolyte. The CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC symmetric battery provides the highest current response (Fig. 6g), indicating it has a superior catalytic conversion ability for LiPSs [32,34]. The lower redox current density of other samples is due to the lack of surface affinity of CBC/SnS2 host material and CBC interlayer for LiPS and its weak chemical adsorption capacity. The three-dimensional heterostructure network of the CBC/SOSC interlayer exposes sufficient active sites to facilitate the anchoring-diffusion-conversion process of LiPS. With a multiple capability toward LiPSs, the interconnected SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure network can serve as LiPS promoter to trigger a rapid polysulfide conversion in the LSBs redox reactions. Besides, Li2S deposition experiments were executed to further explore the advantages of CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC in polysulfide conversion. The potentiostatic discharge profiles of the assembled CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC, CBC/SnS2, and CBC batteries with Li2S8 electrolyte at 2.05 V are exhibited. The i-t curves in Fig. 6(h) consist of three parts, representing the reduction of Li2S8, reduction of Li2S6 and the precipitation of Li2S, respectively [46]. Li2S precipitation capacity of CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC is the highest (188.5 mA h g−1), compared with that of CBC/SnS2 (136.1 mA h g−1) and CBC (76.6 mA h g−1) (Fig. S18), demonstrating that CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC offers active sites to improve nucleation/conversion redox kinetics of Li2S and facilitates the rapid polysulfides conversion and utilization of the active materials [53]. Furthermore, the responsivity of Li2S nucleation on the CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC-based battery is the fastest, which indicates that the CBC/SOSC can reduce the overpotential of Li2S nucleation and accelerate the interfacial electronics transfer kinetics for polysulfides transformation [46]. The above-mentioned results illustrate that CBC/SnS2@CBC/SOSC has a superior combination of LiPSs adsorbing ability, excellent catalytic activity, and good conductivity for the conversion of LiPSs due to the synergy of several factors as illustrated in Fig. 6(i), including: (1) the physical imprisonment of the 3D interconnected carbon fibers of CBC, (2) fast conversion ability of SnS2 micro-flowers, (3) the superior polysulfides-chemisorption ability of SnO2, and (4) enhanced electron and ion propagation ability by the SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure. 2.4 Suppression effect of CBC/SOSC on formation of lithium-dendrites Due to the fact that an internal electric field exists at SnO2–SnS2 heterointerface, CBC/SOSC interlayer possesses the potential to induce uniform lithium deposition and alleviate undesirable electron migration between electrolytes and Li anode simultaneously [51]. To evaluate the suppression effect of the multifunctional CBC/SOSC interlayer on the formation of lithium-dendrites, the long-term cycling stability of Li||Li symmetric batteries with the interlayer of CBC or CBC/SOSC, and without an interlayer were investigated at 0.5 mA cm−2 with an aerial capacity of 0.25 mA h cm−2 (Fig. 7 a). The CBC/SOSC-based Li||Li symmetric battery exhibits a lower voltage hysteresis (12 mV) after cycling 400 h than the CBC-based Li||Li symmetric battery (19 mV) and the Li||Li symmetric battery (41 mV). The low voltage hysteresis guarantees homogeneous lithium deposition [55]. Furthermore, the morphologies of the Li anodes were observed by SEM after the cycling to verify the effect of the interlayer on suppressing the lithium-dendrite formation (Fig. 7b–d and enlarged view in Fig. S19). For the CBC/SOSC-based symmetric battery, the Li anode shows a smooth surface, indicating a stable SEI and homogeneous lithium deposition, while the surface of the Li anodes of the symmetric battery without an interlayer or with CBC interlayer displays an inhomogeneous appearance, indicating the enormous lithium-dendrite formation. In the rate capability tests, the CBC/SOSC-based symmetric battery delivers low voltage hysteresises of 8, 21, 31, 42, and 55 mV at 0.5, 1, 2, 5, and 10 mA cm−2, respectively, as shown in Fig. 7(e). When the current density returns to 0.5 mA cm−2, the overpotential returns to 6 mV, revealing uniform Li anode growth and a stable SEI [54,56]. The CBC-based symmetric battery shows no obvious hysteresis at the low current densities (0.5 and 1 mA cm−2) but very big voltage hysteresis with increasing current density, while the Li||Li symmetric battery shows the biggest voltage hysteresis at all current densities. Besides, even at an ultra-high current density and areal capacity (10 mA cm−2, 5 mA cm−2), CBC/SOSC-based symmetric battery still exhibits a stable voltage hysteresis of 43 mV and maintains a stable cycling performance for 400 h (Fig. 7f), demonstrating the uniform Li+ nucleation and growth, which results from the homogeneous porous structure of 3D carbon-based SnO2–SnS2 heterostructural network and high conductivity of heterointerface [56]. It can be concluded that the CBC/SOSC interlayer with the highly conductive carbon nanofibers coated with a hard inorganic metal heterostructural SnO2–SnS2 can facilitate the uniform Li+ flux and thus suppress lithium-dendrite formation [30,32]. To illustrate fully the uniqueness and advantages of our work, several materials and their performance reported in recent studies are listed in Table S3 for comparison. As shown in Table S3, intensive efforts have been made to overcome the shortcomings of cathodes (low sulfur utilization and shuttling effect) or anodes (lithium-dendrite and anode corrosion) for LSBs, but no systematic designs have been reported to simultaneously alleviate all the above-mentioned problems in dual-side electrodes. We have proposed a completely new idea to synchronously conquer the aforementioned issues of the dual-side electrodes via the synergetic of CBC/SnS2/S and CBC/SOSC. 2.5 Post-cycle characterizations of the both sides of the cells Fig. 8 shows the SEM images of the cathode and anode of the cells working with CBC/S, CBC/SnS2/S, CBC/SnS2/S@CBC, and CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC after 300 cycles at 0.5 C. The SEM image in Fig. 8(a) and Fig. S20(a) shows that the fiber structure of the CBC/S cathode is disrupted. For the CBC/SnS2/S cell, the 3D interconnected carbon network and SnS2 micro-flower structure are no longer visible as shown in Fig. 8(b) and Fig. S20(b), displaying the severe structural damage of sulfur host material. For the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC cell, the damage to the carbon network structure also occurs, but the close contact between the SnS2 micro-flowers and CBC fibers can still be observed as shown in Fig. 8(c) and Fig. S20(c). As displayed in Fig. 8(d) and Fig. S20(d), CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC preserves the relatively integrated structure of SnS2 nanoflowers embedded in the 3D interconnected CBC network without the massive fiber damage. The superior post-cycle morphology of the cathodic side of the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC cell can result from a “burden-sharing” effect that the combination of SnS2 host with CBC/SOSC can share the burden of the CBC physically and/or electrochemically, which alleviates structural damage to CBC and guarantees the constant conductivity across the cathodic side. We can conclude that the CBC/SOSC multifunctional interlayer not only facilitates the unobstructed LiPSs anchoring-conversion reaction on the cathode side of the LSBs by the 3D interconnected carbon-based SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure, but also ensures the structural stability of the CBC/SnS2 cathode material [57]. For the anodic side, a large number of deposited sulfides and lithium-dendrites appear on the Li anode surfaces of the cells with CBC/S, CBC/SnS2/S, and CBC/SnS2/S@CBC, respectively as shown in Fig. 8(e–g) (enlarged view in Fig. S21), mainly due to inefficient suppress of the polysulfides shuttling [39]. In contrast, the SEM image in Fig. 8(h) shows a relatively smooth Li anode surface for the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC cell, without the mossy-like deposition and lithium-dendrites, which indicates that the CBC/SOSC interlayer can achieve timely adsorption-conversion for the polysulfides and prompt the uniform Li+ flux across the separator to avoid the lithium-dendrite formation [56]. As illustrated in Fig. 8(i), the advantages of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC for the achieved enhanced lithium-storage performances, in terms of discharging capacity, rate capability, and cycling stability, can be summarized as follows: i) The multi-layer SnS2 micro-flowers evenly distributed in the 3D interconnected CBC conductive network provide a large number of active sites for the rapid catalytic conversion of sulfur, promoting the redox kinetics of the cathode. ii) The CBC/SOSC interlayer with the SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure can achieve the enhanced adsorption-diffusion-conversion effect to suppress the polysulfide migration from the cathodic side to the anodic one. iii) The distinctive 3D interconnected carbon-based heterostructure network with the uniform microporous size, small average pore size, and internal electric field of the heterointerfaces can facilitate uniform lithium deposition and growth. These synergetic advantages of the CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC battery with the promising electrochemical performance, even in the case of high sulfur loading and at high current density, provide a good strategy for the development of practical high-energy–density and long-life LSBs as well as other energy storage batteries. 3 Conclusions We propose a stepwise “catalysis-adsorption-conversion” hierarchical functionalization strategy that the cathode material and the interlayer material specifically establish their respective functions in the LSBs. The feasible CBC/SnS2 sulfur host and the multifunctional CBC/SOSC interlayer based on the natural 3D interconnected network BC material were co-applied into LSBs to solve the issues that are arising on the both sides and deteriorate LSBs: (1) polysulfide shuttling and low sulfur utilization on the cathodic side and (2) electrode corrosion and lithium-dendrite formation on the anodic side. The CBC/SnS2 sulfur host equipped with enormous active sites can enhance the electrocatalytic reaction of sulfur species, achieving the high sulfur utilizations even with elevated sulfur loadings. The CBC/SOSC interlayer multifunctionally facilitated the lithium-storage performance of LSBs: (1) CBC/SOSC promoted the rapid anchoring-diffusion-conversion process of LiPSs through the 3D carbon-based network anchored with SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure. (2) CBC/SOSC suppressed the polysulfide shuttling, which reduced the anode corrosion and further enhanced the sulfur utilization. (3) CBC/SOSC can evenly regulate the Li+ flux and significantly alleviate the lithium-dendrite formation. The CBC in both sulfur host and interlayer with hierarchical porosity profitably improved the cycling stability of LSBs by buffering volume change of the cathode. Taking the advantage of the combination of CBC/SnS2 with CBC/SOSC, the cell delivered much enhanced electrochemical performance including reversible capacity, rate capability, and cycling stability. Moreover, the impressive discharge capacity (859.5 mA h g−1) under high sulfur mass loading (5.2 mg cm−2) highlighted the practical application potential of CBC/SnS2/S@CBC/SOSC. Our stepwise functionalization synergistic strategy of the rapidly catalytic sulfur host with the light multifunctional interlayer sheds light on the future rational design of high-performance LSBs. coredata.dc:description: With the high theoretical specific capacity and energy density, lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have been intensively studied as promising candidates for energy storage devices. However, LSBs are largely hindered by inferior sulfur utilization and uncontrollable dendritic growth. Herein, a hierarchical functionalization strategy of stepwise catalytic-adsorption-conversion for sulfur species via the synergetic of the efficiently catalytic host cathode and light multifunctional interlayer has been proposed to concurrently address the issues arising on the dual sides of the LSBs. The multi-layer SnS2 micro-flowers embedded into the natural three-dimensional (3D) interconnected carbonized bacterial cellulose (CBC) nanofibers are fabricated as the sulfur host that provides numerous catalytic sites for the rapid catalytic conversion of sulfur species. Moreover, the distinctive CBC-based SnO2–SnS2 heterostructure network accompanied high conductive carbon nanofibers as the multifunctional interlayer promotes the rapid anchoring-diffusion-conversion of lithium polysulfides, Li+ flux redistribution, and uniform Li deposition. LSBs equipped with our strategy exhibit a high reversible capacity of 1361.5 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and superior cycling stability with an ultra-low capacity fading of 0.031% per cycle in 1000 cycles at 1.5 C and 0.046% at 3 C. A favorable specific capacity of 859.5 mA h g−1 at 0.3 C is achieved with a high sulfur mass loading of 5.2 mg cm−2, highlighting the potential of practical application. The rational design in this work can provide a feasible solution for high-performance LSBs and promote the development of advanced energy storage devices.
